results.title: Project grizzly
results.creator_credit: Peter Lynch, Michael Allder and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Troy Hurtubise on 18th May 2002, once again made the news with a demonstration of his latest grizzly bear suit ‘Ursus Mark VII’. ‘Project grizzly’ documents his story. Troy Hurtubise’s obsession was given birth to over 10 years ago when he was confronted by a grizzly bear whilst trekking alone in the Canadian wilderness. Under an extraordinary set of circumstances the grizzly spares Troy’s life and so an obsession is born. The task Troy set himself is to build a suit that will withstand an attack from a grizzly bear. The mission is to again confront ‘Old Man’ (Troy’s name for the grizzly) whilst wearing the suit to continue his “close quarter bear research”. After $150,000 has been spent and 6 proto-types later Troy takes us through the joys and tribulations of his experimentation whilst admitting that he suffers from claustrophobia. By the end of the documentary we see Troy in suit being bashed with base-ball bats, lead balls and hit by a 3-tonne truck travelling at 50km/h - 18 times! So will Troy get his sniff of ‘Old Man’ or will the transport of the suit impede the project? Also shown is a reconstructed Ska-Nah-Doht, a traditional Iroquoian village.

results.title: Project expansion
results.creator_credit: Robert Walker, Ross Wood and Ross Wood Productions
results.brief_description: A major expansion program, begun by New Broken Hill Consolidated Ltd, in 1968, was completed in 1971. The film describes the expansion activities, which included the sinking of a three-thousand foot air shaft and major extensions to the underground workings. Many views of modern mining methods are provided. Could be used for geography, secondary social studies, and for general interest.

results.title: Profession of arms
results.creator_credit: Alex Ezard and Artransa Park Studios
results.brief_description: Life as a cadet at Duntroon - history and background. Shows National War Museum at Canberra and Duntroon - Australias only military college - established in 1911, as part of a defence plan recommended by Field Marshall Lord Kitchener. Royal Military College is an intensive four year course in academic and military training affiliated with the University of NSW.

results.title: Problem of acceptance
results.brief_description: A condensation of the therapy session held with patients of the psychiatric ward of the University of Oregon Medical School. The theme is a psychodramtic exploration of a 17 year old girl’s attempt to deal with her homosexuality.

results.title: Problem clinic
results.creator_credit: Ronald Weyman, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Few people, faced with the complicated machinery of the law, know how to proceed without legal counsel or defence. Yet many are unable to pay for the services of a lawyer. The Law Societies of many of the provinces, encouraged by the Canadian Bar Association, extend help in the form of free legal-aid clinics staffed by volunteer lawyers. Enacted here is a case in which a young man facing a criminal charge is defended by a legal-aid lawyer.

results.title: Privilege
results.brief_description: A pre-eminenent feminist experimental filmmaker and performer, Yvonne Rainer has been making films since the seventies. Her work utilises a variety of art and media forms to create a multi-layered series of images and texts that convey her deep interest in human relationships. “Privilege” is a reflexive narrative which employs found and staged interviews, fragments of drama and graphic inserts on a computer screen to disjunctively range over the themes of menopause, racism and rape, from which the viewer is required to distil meaning on the issues of sexual and class identity. Cast includes Alice Spirak and Blaire Baron.

results.title: Privates on parade
results.creator_credit: Michael Blakemore, Simon Relph and Hand Made Films
results.brief_description: To fight the good fight, British soldiers in Southeast Asia will need to laugh the good laugh. That’s where Major Giles Flack (John Cleese) and his morale-boosting theatrical troup led by the gloriously high-camp Acting Captain Terri Dennis (Denis Quilley) come in. The war and the show must go on! A farcical musical comedy underscored by the realities of war. Screenplay and lyrics by Peter Nichols based on his own play “Privates on parade”, music composed and conducted by Denis King. Cast also includes Nicola Pagett, Patrick Pearson, Joe Melia, Simon Jones, Michael Elphick, John Standing. Executive producer - George Harrison (Beatles). Contains b&w scenes.

results.title: Private and confidential
results.creator_credit: Joe Bogdanov and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: It was the first time a boy had kissed me. I felt as though I was reeling, soaring drowning-all at once, I gave myself completely to his lips! So thinks the teenage heroine of this in-depth look at True Romance Comix. The stage is set for Joan’s undoing. Useful for exploring popular culture, sexism and melodrama. Winner, Diploma of Merit, Melbourne Film Festival, 1984.

results.title: Prisoners of propaganda
results.brief_description: In 1943, the Imperial Japanese Army Secret Service forced a group of Australian servicemen to appear in a film to show the “exemplary” conditions under which Prisoners of War were treated by Japan. This program looks at the mysterious story behind that film, titled, Calling Australia.
